title: What will be the closing price of wheat in the US on 15 June 2022?
possible_answers: More than 1,075.00 but less than 1,200.00, inclusive
preds: Got wrong figures earlier. Now at 1065. It'll be a wild ride on Wednesday so another forecast right on the very edge. How do they do it at GJP \o/ ?!
2 days left to go. The past 5 days have closed just barely under 1075. I'm shifting my forecast further to <1075.
Narrowing forecast as time goes on

Yet another forecast on the verge, dangling by inches between two choices, just days before closing. Uncanny. Global wheat supply continues to be under threat from Russia's war in Ukraine and the USDA predicts lower production for 2022 and 2023.  Price went up by as much as 5.2% on Monday "against a backdrop of poor harvest forecasts and an India-Egypt trade deal". Chicago wheat futures were up 5.1% to $10.93 per bushel from their previous close of $10.45. (Price today was at $1,077 right on the edge).  Russia's Lavrov met with Turkey's Erdogan yesterday to discuss access to Black Sea ports and suddenly wheat prices dropped (about .16%) Both countries voiced support following their meeting "for a safe corridor in the Black Sea to allow Ukrainian grain exports, but Kyiv rejected the proposal, saying it was not credible." AP "Russia also demanded Ukraine remove mines from the Black Sea, and both Moscow and Ankara said the West should ease sanctions on Moscow to allow the export of Russian grains amid an escalating world food crisis. While food exports are technically exempt from the sanctions, Russia claims that restrictions on its ships and banks make it impossible to deliver its grain to global markets."  Turkey knows too well that the next front of the Russian invasion of Ukraine will be over the Black Sea (access to ports, escorting ships transporting grain) so it should not come as a surprise that Erdogan went on a Twitter rant today threatening Greece. As part of the rant, Erdogan said that "Turkey will not relinquish its rights in the Aegean and will not refrain from using the powers granted to it by international agreements for the armament of the islands when necessary" and went on as far as saying "Including demilitarized islands in various exercises and seeking to use NATO and third party countries as a tool in this unlawfulness is nothing but an effort that will have a tragic ending." It looks like Turkey is playing its cards and using their power over the Black Sea situation as a bargaining chip to address pending issues and grievances. If this is the case, then both Russia and now Turkey are most likely to continue to weaponize food supply to get advantage at war (as per the EU).   We may see prices move slightly but just enough to go slightly below or above $1,075. Since wheat prices are expected to continue to go up given the unresolved situation, I'll go with the slightly higher side above 1,075 and see what happens in the next 6 days.  https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-turkey-middle-east-sergey-lavrov-6f0447bfa71448f2c4b8f78a7414ce45
I think there might be a slightly downward trend, but this question could end up on either side of 1075.
Sorry just amending my forecast as oil prices are in fact still high. Lower likelihood of them falling below 1075 this week therefore.

Adjusting my forecast as the price has been trending down since April, and despite large spikes has only gone above 1200 for short periods. The main drivers of price rises - war in Ukraine and Indian heatwave - ought to be priced in and are not likely to add further pressure in the next week. Oil prices are down a lot, which takes the other big factor in price rises away. The Chinese economy continues to suffer greatly, and global inflation in other sectors and commodities may further tamp demand and thus wheat prices.   So although prices have not dropped below 1075 for more than a couple of days in the last quarter, the chances of them dropping that low again next week are not much less than the chances of them spiking above 1200 again.
I don’t know the figures - or how to read the data I should say … question closing in 7hrs ==1050.25 https://www.cmegroup.com/markets/agriculture/grains/kc-wheat.contractSpecs.html
Only 8 more calendar days in the forecast, so I'm going to lower my forecast on the last bin. Prices are currently straddling the 1075 line, so I'll split my forecast around it.
There's so much volatility that I think it's hard to justify strong preference for any of the top 3 bins at this time.

Prices are trending slightly up with today's morning trading, so I'll shift my forecast slightly upward. This may or may not be related to some of the news below about Russia's efforts to prevent Ukraine from exporting grain - but also Russia's efforts to sell some of Ukraine's grain that it looted. Russia destroyed a major grain export terminal in Mykolaiv and is taking steps to block future exports from the Black Sea coast.https://twitter.com/Biz_Ukraine_Mag/status/1533382115336790016https://twitter.com/SamRamani2/status/1533727714041110528 Also, yesterday, "The target of the Russian missile attacked in Kyiv this morning was a facility that works on railway cars to transport grain. Officials let us in to have a look. The place is gutted."https://twitter.com/shustry/status/1533480796807389187 But Russia is trying to sell stolen Ukrainian grain to countries in Africa. "The U.S. alerted 14 countries, mostly in Africa, that Russian ships carrying stolen Ukrainian grain could be headed their way, posing a dilemma to countries facing dire food shortages."https://twitter.com/nytimes/status/1533801393210933248 But, "Africans don’t care where they get their food from, and if someone is going to moralize about that, they are mistaken"https://twitter.com/SamRamani2/status/1533732659452694528
informed by a Monte Carlo simulation
I think it will probably resolve in bin 4 or 5, but which one seems almost a toss-up at the moment, so I don't want to put too much more weight on bin 4 vs. 5 yet.

The trend since May 17 is downward, and I expect that that overall trend will continue, unless there is some new shock to the market. As the current price is 1058.2, I expect that a couple weeks from now, the price is slightly more likely to be under 1075 than above it; the price is pretty volatile, so prices could bounce above and below the 1075 dividing line between bins. I don't think there's any realistic chance that the price will be <950, as it hasn't been <950 since early March.

I think there's a significant chance that the price will drift down over the next couple weeks and end up bumping around 1100 or so. I can only picture the price ending up above 1200 if there is a new, significant shock.
Ok, the price has come back down below 1200, and I think it will likely stay below 1200.

It's at 1191 today, 27 days from challenge closure. I definitely think there could be more buying pressure as other countries ban wheat exports, but USDA reports indicate spring wheat planting was only 1% off the prior year.  https://www.dtnpf.com/agriculture/web/ag/news/article/2022/03/31/corn-futures-rise-soybean-futures
I think the price will probably fall below 1200 by June 15. It could even fall into bin 4.
Prices do seem to be coming off a high on news from India.
No sign yet of wheat coming back down... but as prices are so volatile, I'll keep my forecast spread widely.
I kind of expect prices to fall a bit after a spike up on India’s news, but then again, they might not.

There is a long shot chance that an agreement to open the port of Odessa can be reached.  That would put downward pressure on the global price of wheat.  It's doubtful that it will occur at all, unless the so-called global South puts a lot of pressure on Russia.  India and much of Africa are facing food shortages if Ukrainian wheat cannot be shipped to market.  If an agreement does happen it's unlikely in the next four weeks. With the price today of nearly $12.50 per bushel, and less than one month left, I'll continue overweight the higher bins.
India wheat export ban. India accounts for 4% of global wheat exports. The price has apparently gone up 6% on the news.

The price continued to go up last night and only this morning seems to be coming off a high (1198.4) very close to 1200. With only 23 trading days left after today, current prices at higher levels on the USDA reports, and closing prices above 950 since March 1, I'm zeroing out bin 3. I don't think the closing price on June 15 will be above 1200 right now, but prices have been so close to that today and yesterday that I think it's a real possibility. The market could continue to react slowly to the USDA news and bump prices generally higher next week. Or, the market could fall back a little and hover in bins 4 and 5. Given the slightly higher prices now, I think bin 5 is most likely at the moment.

Big USDA report day today, and wheat has moved up dramatically today. Nice analysis of why here: https://www.barchart.com/story/news/8340366/wheats-up-double-digitsWith the price of fertilizer up, even though wheat prices are up, wheat acreage planted has fallen. Wheat needs fertilizer, but soybeans don't.The July '22 (ZWN22) price spiked to 1183.0 a little big ago, moving up 70.4 just today, but has fallen from that peak to 1170.0 so far. I can't picture prices falling below 1000 by June 15 at this point, though, even with volatility, and I think there's a bit more risk of the last bin than I thought before. (I follow July '22 CBOT wheat because the source data are W.1 CBOT wheat, which is front month wheat, i.e., the closest futures contract for CBOT wheat that can be purchased, and I think this question will be resolved using July '22 CBOT wheat data. If I'm wrong, then it'll be resolved using Sep '22 CBOT wheat data, which is very similar anyway.)https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/ZWN22/overview
Looking again, if prices continue to drift down, bin 3 would be possible.

The price range is looking pretty stable. I think bins 3 and 6 both look extremely unlikely at this point, with only 43 calendar days to go in the forecast. Sep 2022 futures have been between 950 and 1200 since March 4. It looks slightly more likely to me that the price will slowly drift downwards a little over the remainder of the question, but I wouldn't rule out a slight drift upward, either. I think it would take a major shock to see the price go over 1200, and I don't see what the source of such a shock would be at this time.
Apparently prices aren't going down in the near future. Planting is experiencing delays. https://www.farmprogress.com/morning-market-review/wheat-rallies-rating-downgrade-planting-delays
Forecast based on a Monte Carlo simulation balanced against the crowd forecast.

I had thought this question would resolve with July 22 futures prices, but it looks like it'll resolve with Sept 22 futures prices: 
https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/ZWU22/overview
Not much different. I still think it's likely prices will gently decline with noise.

The trend is slowly downward, and more than 2 months remain in this forecast.
https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/ZWN22/overview
Surprising moves in July wheat today so far.

The last bin is looking less likely to me at the moment. July 22 futures prices (which I think is the month that will resolve this question) spiked on news of the invasion of Ukraine but have come down and stabilized at just under $1100, oscillating between bins 4 and 5. The trend in the price of wheat has been steadily upward throughout the pandemic, in large part because of changes in demand but also because of changes in input costs, including fertilizer costs. I suspect that that underlying upward trend will likely continue, but it's looking decreasingly likely to me that prices will end up over 1200. But, there are 2.5 months between now and the end of the question, and a lot can happen between now and then, so I don't rule it out. I think it's unlikely but not impossible that prices will go back to their pre-invasion range in the forecast period.
Agreeing with @belikewater, futures rate should have Ukraine factored in, but it's going to get worse before it gets better, so 1,100 is my sweet spot.
Will Ukrainian farmers get to plant enough in planting season?

This question is probably going to be resolved with July 22 futures prices. The July 22 futures price is currently 1044.6: https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/ZWN22/overview
I'm not sure whether wheat prices will continue to increase, but I suspect they will, as the effects of the Ukraine invasion are felt on the spring wheat crop and exports.

Combined, Russia and Ukraine produce almost 25% of global wheat supply. Most of the crop is winter wheat which is harvested in July/August (prior to close of question). If aggression in Ukraine continues longer-term, then the harvest is at risk and will substantially affect prices. Additionally, wheat output is at risk in several areas due to ongoing drought. Update: Raised probability to $1200+. Price was over $1200 today, but the reason I adjusted was that prior spikes in wheat price took months to resolve after peaking. If that same trend continues, we cannot expect this to drop back down before June. Also, the war in Ukraine seems likely to be protracted - this even further reduces the likelihood that we would see wheat prices fall. Lastly - wheat crop is China could be the worst ever (https://www.reuters.com/business/china-ensure-agricultural-product-supplies-including-grains-2022-03-05/)  Update 3/15: No change to forecast with increased info.  
Most of US crop is already planted; benefit to farmers to plant more wheat is being offset by the sharp increases in fuel and fertilizer costs (large imports from Russia/Belarus).  While the US is the 2nd largest producer of wheat, but domestic supply is at the lowest level in 14 years.  There's also a drought in Kansas/Montana.  Great article from FT (https://www.ft.com/content/6faa1318-ca75-4cae-8d78-bc99d24bc1bd)
A correction and stabilisation in price before June is looking more likely

Ukraine will be unable to plant spring wheat in much of the country.  Most wheat in the US is winter wheat, i.e., planted in the fall.  [No source cited, but my father was a wheat farmer.]   Crops are often rotated to maintain the right balance of nutrients in the soil, and fertilizer and other costs are currently very high.  Lastly, the weather is always a wild card regarding crop yields.  For these reasons it seems unlikely the price will decrease.  OTOH, unexpected things happen when there is a lot of money to be made.

Current futures prices for July hover at $1,074, however this is down from recent highs attributed to the Russia/Ukraine invasion. Given that April will mark the start of the northern hemisphere planting season, I expect farmers will consider planting outsized crops to take advantage of higher prices, potentially offsetting some of the shortage. A headline today also notes that Ukraine will attempt to continue to export agricultural goods despite the invasion. Therefore I believe the price may hover very close to the $1,075 figure on June 15
>ukraine/russia conflict effect on wheat supply, stability should be affected for awhile (further research on avg length of time to stability post conflict tbd in future forecasts)

Note: My response assumes the outcome options are incorrectly labeled as dollars($) and should instead be interpreted as "U.S. cents per bushel" (see CME link) "$1,200.00" is actually "$12.00" or "¢1,200.00"
Several developments in today's headlines. Updating accordingly: https://open.spotify.com/episode/3mlSOcV00dmheW9dKC3wX5?si=7WsF548bSouNeYec68G4hw&context=spotify%3Aplaylist%3A6p21dRudS9FmcyGvKWPq2R

https://tradingeconomics.com/commodity/wheat - looks optimistic, but would the occupation of Ukraine prevent the export of wheat , and when people are starving would we not buy wheat from Russia? Ongoing peace talks may result in a few deals around commodities.

An initail market shock due to Ukraine conflict has sent prices soaring, however overall Ukraine represents a modest percentage of the global wheat production. With US crops likely to stay vs exports think the overall trends will return to only a slight bump in the year-over year averages.

Due to widespread drought in the west of the country, USDA had been predicting slightly higher US wheat prices prior to Russia's invasion of Ukraine; reduction of Russian exports related to the invasion exacerbates this. However, Russia has been imposing export quotas and taxes that have historically eased it out of the market during the months in question, and other producers (China, India, Australia) can help fill the gap. As of March 9, the price was already beginning to drop. Too soon to say for sure, but a regression towards the mean seems probable. https://www.ers.usda.gov/webdocs/outlooks/103245/whs-22b.pdf?v=9079.9

A roll of the die chance of a spike but really, we think a sustained $1200+ price is likely or possible?
https://economics21.org/wheat-prices-are-rising

There is a 10 year cycle, a great chance to have prices above $1000 References: https://qz.com/india/2138440/the-russia-ukraine-could-make-india-a-key-wheat-exporter/?utm_source=YPL
https://tradingeconomics.com/commodity/wheat
https://www.nasdaq.com/market-activity/commodities/zw

Combined, Russia and Ukraine produce almost 25% of global wheat supply. Most of the crop is winter wheat which is harvested in July/August (prior to close of question). If aggression in Ukraine continues longer-term, then the harvest is at risk and will substantially affect prices. Additionally, wheat output is at risk in several areas due to ongoing drought. If that same trend continues, we cannot expect this to drop back down before June.  Also, the war in Ukraine seems likely to be protracted - this even further reduces the likelihood that we would see wheat prices fall.
Current price is about $1250 already and the futures are on an upward trend. The Ukrainian wheat of this years crop will rot and never enter the market.

Reuters: China agriculture minister says winter wheat condition could be worst in history
https://www.reuters.com/business/china-ensure-agricultural-product-supplies-including-grains-2022-03-05/
"BEIJING, March 5 (Reuters) - The condition of China's winter wheat crop could be the "worst in history", the agriculture minister said on Saturday, raising concerns about grain supplies in the world's biggest wheat consumer."
"A survey of the winter wheat crop taken before the start of winter found that the amount of first- and second-grade crop was down by more than 20 percentage points, Tang said."
"However, Tang is confident China can ensure a bumper harvest of summer grain thanks to strong policy and technical support and the improving crop condition for the grain." (But that would be after the forecast period.)
Never underestimate the likelihood of an open-ended bin.  Wheat could be at $12/bushel or $20/bushel due to the Russia/Ukraine war.

Rethinking. The war in Ukraine is almost certainly not going to be over. That means exports from both Ukraine and Russia will be affected, and they are the source of 25% of the world's wheat exports. I don't think their export volume will fall to zero, but I don't see a scenario in which serious shocks won't be felt.
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2022/2/17/infographic-russia-ukraine-and-the-global-wheat-supply-interactive

I got wrapped up in the Ukraine forecasts and didn't pay enough attention to this one.
I think prices might come down a bit from the spike, wherever it ends, but probably not too much, as Ukraine's crops and exports - and Russia's - may be affected a lot.

Wheat had been rising at the rate of about $11/mo since 2019, so I'd normally expect it to be about $840 in June. The thing driving the wheat price spike, of course, is uncertainty, and uncertainty will subside if the war stops - but not by much. So that bucket will be my floor. Wheat has, in fact, been over $1200 in the past, and is again. As @orchidny helpfully noted, Russia+Ukraine constitute about 1/3 of global wheat supply. But the supply is not static: high prices will bring new growers online, which will drive futures prices down. But I don't expect it to resolve uncertainty very much. But **I** am uncertain, of course. I'll just plant a flag here.

This Financial Times article explains why wheat prices are high, and could go higher still.  See https://on.ft.com/3IYmviY Russia and Belarus are the largest exporters of fertilizer.  30% of the world's wheat exports come from Ukraine and Russia, and those exports are now cut off from the global market.  With the war in Ukraine looking like a long slog, the global food security situation could get very bad.

As of writing this wheat prices have spiked to $1141.8. The highest it has been since 2008. The root cause of this recent spike  appears to be conflict in Ukraine and Russia (Accounting for ~30% of global wheat exports) with the ongoing conflict shutting down commercial ports in both Ukraine and Russia along the Black Sea. This does not appear to be changing any time soon, the conflict is still developing in the early stages with the region along the Black sea being the most likely to continue being involved in conflict. To add to this droughts in parts of the US, Canada, and South America appear likely to put even further downward pressure on supply for wheat and maize. Which is likely to keep upward pressures on the price of wheat. While wheat prices are already extremely elevated compared to historical averages, this rational for elevated prices seems founded in the facts and unlikely to resolve any time soon. I think the most likely case is that wheat stays elevated around where it currently is after it's large move to the upside as the factors creating this spike are unlikely to resolve any time soon.

Wheat production based on demand was at record levels before the invasion of Ukraine which will have a detrimental effect on close to 1/3 of wheat production.
Russia will  move to “weaponize” wheat supply in order to assert global influence. Russia has moved into a war time economy and more likely than not martial law will be declared shortly. In war time economies all resources are weaponized to become means to an end.
If Russia is able to export its wheat to China then China would then be responsible for global distribution which would raise the price.
  Russia’s fertilizer industry will be hit hard by sanctions which will effect production costs for wheat. None of this news is any good news and all will contribute to record prices for wheat. https://nationalinterest.org/feature/will-russia-weaponize-its-wheat-world-combats-coronavirus-165031?amp 
https://www.wm.edu/offices/global-research/research-labs/pips/_documents/pips/2017-2018/nelson.collin.summary.pdf https://www.dtnpf.com/agriculture/web/ag/crops/article/2022/01/27/russia-ukraine-conflict-cause-supply

Ukraine production isn’t that significant. 4/5% of top 10 producers. Cant move market too much for too long
But wheat is tight 2021/22
It’s risen from c800 to over 1000
Futures say 750 to 1050
It’s only been over 1000 once before in 2008 and then only for months 
Hard / impossible to see it slipping below 825 for long given uncertainty and timings of seasons and limited ability for production to adjust as planted in autumn. Cant give that more than 5%
Question is whether this price will hold this long at these levels 
War/uncertainty likely to have subsided by 15 June but damage found be huge
Never been above 1200 so whilst possible, hard to put more than 10% on that. 10% fair as unique times
Real ball game is options 3, 4 and 5 so that splits the 85 odd
Slight sense that the high range of over 1075 less likely than the other two due to time lag from now, market size of Ukraine and historic prices so have that at 20
3 and 4 at 30 odd

The Sanctions to Russia will impact the wheat trade market.  Ukraine with war will have trouble making the 4% contribiution to the worl wheat production they delivered.   Even with that the costs of Wheat are moving upwards worldwide since some time.  The only thing that could push them backwards would be a total covid recuperation but this will not happen until 2024

may 1057
july 1010 3/3 (edit) - this is well into the fifth bin now, but it has the look and feel of a panic spike, so I'm sticking here for now.

Wheat prices are higher than at any point in the last 25 years. Wheat production in Ukraine is likely to be heavily disrupted. Oil prices are also extremely high, and likely to go higher because of disruption to supply caused by Putin's War. Oil and natural gas are important precursors to the main fertilisers, supplies of which are already restricted because of new Chinese export restrictions. There are all sorts of factors likely to push prices even higher than they are today.

As expected, price of wheat climbed to its highest level in a decade following invasion of Ukraine. Wheat futures closed up 5.35% at 984 cent per bushel (it was 985.5 in April 4, 2008). 
Of the 207 million ton international wheat trade, 17% comes from Russia, 12% from Ukraine -- so 29% of the world's supply is affected by the current crisis. Wheat, corn, soybean, sunflower prices all on the rise. Futures begin to drop in price only after June/July. Even after conflict is resolved in terms of a cease fire, it will take a while for Ukraine to be rebuild. Russia's economy is also taking a big hit and it's not expected all would come to back to normal immediately. 
https://www.zmp.de/en/grains/cbot-wheat_future
extended sanctions -> Ukraine and Russia 30% of the export market
Wheat will rise but it's a relatively stable market aside from the most recent shock
It's probably too late for a break in the drought to save this years crop.

may futures at 984
july futures at 957
Believe 750 - 850 range (based on 2021-2022 chart will likely be where Wheat gravitates toward after Russia conflict
I see strong upward pressure continuing w/ inflation likely to run hot amid worsening supply chain struggles; negative catalyst being end to war

Combined, Russia and Ukraine produce almost 25% of global wheat supply. Most of the crop is winter wheat which is harvested in July/August (prior to close of question).  If aggression in Ukraine continues longer-term, then the harvest is at risk and will substantially affect prices.  Additionally, wheat output is at risk in several areas due to ongoing drought.
I don't know enough about this yet, so this is my opening forecast.

Skewing higher than the crowd, but not too far.  We don't yet know what the crop yields will be this year, and we don't know if Ukrainian wheat will be able to transit via the Black Sea.  There are so many questions that depend on the war in Ukraine -- inflation, Biden's popularity, interest rates, oil prices, etc.  And the situation in Ukraine is changing every day.  The good news is that the world is now more united than ever in opposition to Russia's military aggression.  Today we are all Ukrainians.

Taking a long term perspective prices are already high were expected to stabilise or fall in 2022 (as was the case before last week).  So if the situation in Ukraine does not influence prices in June than the most likely scenario seems to be bin 2, with the possibility that shortages drive prices higher into bin 3 (less wheat was produced than consumed in 2020 and 2021 - partly weather/crop yield related at least in 2021) absent export shortages (which maybe some countries have prepared for) . As I have ignored other bins I will adjust regularly as I can monitor daily prices to see a change in trend as well as qualitative news. https://www.marketwatch.com/story/why-prices-for-wheat-have-climbed-to-their-highest-level-since-2012-11636653340
Prices spiked with the invasion of Ukraine, but seem to be coming down again. A lot can happen in about four months.

My prior ist around 725 because it's approximately the median of the price of wheat from 2021. That's my external view.
Then, with what's happening in Ukraine now, it's reasonable to suspect production going down, and price going up. The santions against Russia may put the price up to. Nonetheless, 15th june is almost in 4 monthts. I bet the crisis will kind of stabilize because I think the attempts to keep the worldwide more or less peaceful state will be pretty big (I could be wrong). That's my inside view.
So my bet for the 26th of february is that the price will go up, but not dramatically, so between 825 and 950€ seems the most likely for me. The farther price gets from it, the less likely I bet it will happen. See you on next update !

I'm making a rough initial prediction. Russia and Ukraine are the world's third and eighth largest wheat producers. It seems a logical conclusion that given the conflict and sanctions that prices will rise. Source: https://fortune.com/2022/02/24/100-oil-russia-invasion-ukraine-prices-bread-steel/

CBOT wheat this time.
There can obviously be huge volatility in wheat prices, so even if one forecasts the trend correctly, it's can be hard to get the price on a given day correct.
Before the recent price spike, the trend price was around $800. It's currently at $862. I don't picture it being likely to go much below that. I'd suspect that the trend price might go up by ~10% if Ukraine's production is substantially affected. Add on top of that expected increases in price due to high fertilizer prices. Barring WWIII, I can't picture prices going ultra-high, but I'm leaving my options open.
